author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What Will Happen to Bloomberg After Its Founder Steps Away?
description: A leadership reshuffle at the financial data giant has rekindled questions about a future sale or a move to take the company public.
content: What will happen to Bloomberg L.P. after Mike Bloomberg steps away? That question resurfaced last week after the billionaire, 81, announced leadership changes and a new board for  the company he founded in 1981 after leaving Salomon Brothers. (That said, he told employees that he’s “not going anywhere.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Franne Lee, Tony Winner Who Also Costumed Coneheads, Dies at 81
description: She worked on “Sweeney Todd” and “Candide” and also on the early seasons of “Saturday Night Live,” contributing to the look of the Blues Brothers and the Killer Bees.
content: Franne Lee, a costume and set designer who while doing Tony Award-winning work on Broadway in the 1970s also made killer-bee suits and cone-shaped headwear for early “Saturday Night Live” sketches, helping to create some of that era’s most memorable comic moments, died on Sunday in Atlantis, Fla. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include cute-robot charm and alien abduction angst.
content: From the start, it’s obvious that this is not a regular Kaiju movie. The genre, in which gigantic beasts à la Godzilla lay waste to cities and swaths of countryside, is not known for restraint, but “Shin Ultraman” is completely, unpredictably off the wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Partisan Politics Put a Huge Win for Public Health at Risk
description: The loss of support for an AIDS relief program would signal to the rest of the world that it could no longer rely on the U.S. to defend its biggest accomplishments as a leader in global health.
content: At the end of 2001, not long after George W. Bush became president, there were 40 million people across the globe living with H.I.V./AIDS, which was usually a death sentence for those who lacked access to treatment. Most people with H.I.V. lived on the continent of Africa, where 2.3 million died of AIDS that year. There were widespread estimates that 100 million worldwide would die of AIDS in the following 20 years if something wasn’t done to better distribute treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a monkey’s quest, a splashy version of a beloved Nintendo franchise and a Lego adventure packed with Disney princesses.
content: This Netflix original is based on “Journey to the West,” a famous 16th-century Chinese novel written during the Ming dynasty. The story follows a magical monkey named Sun Wukong — voiced here by Jimmy O. Yang and referred to only as Monkey King — who is born from a rock and cast out by the other monkeys in the forest. Growing up, he longs to be one of the all-powerful Immortals. He goes on a quest to hell and back to defeat 100 demons, the requirement to fulfill his dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: For 50 Years, Emanuel Ax Has Made Music Sound Simply Right
description: Understated and unarrogant, Ax can be taken for granted. But he has long been, and continues to be, one of the finest American pianists.
content: “A young pianist with the hard-to-forget name of Emanuel Ax has one thing going for him before he plays a note,” the New York Times critic Donal Henahan wrote in 1973. “But brand identification, as advertising men term it, helps in the long run only if the product delivers, and Mr. Ax’s recital at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night fortunately carried the stamp of quality.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These Great Movies Before They Leave Netflix in September
description: This month’s losses for U.S. subscribers include some of the most beloved titles and characters ever to grace a screen.
content: The titles leaving Netflix in the United States are a real smorgasbord this month, from genre movies to children’s fare to two of the most beloved Oscar winners in cinematic history. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Superstar Cities in the Age of Zoom
description: Will big metros lose their edge? Or will remote work make them stronger?
content: On Friday morning, just before writing this newsletter, I spoke to a conference of the Regional Science Association in Alicante, Spain. Notice the choice of preposition: “to,” not “at.” Given family commitments, I couldn’t attend in person, so this was a Zoom presentation from home — something we’ve all become familiar with over the past three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: Finding Her ‘Barack Obama’ With the Help of a Friend
description: Olivia Castor and Austin McNair met at Harvard through Ms. Castor’s roommate, who had a knack for matchmaking.
content: One day in April 2017, during the spring semester of her senior year at Harvard, Olivia Melissa Castor received a call from her roommate, who said, “Liv, I found your Barack Obama.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: The Latest Summer Fad in the Hamptons: Clay Catering on Demand
description: Hamptonites can’t get enough of pottery wheels in their backyards. One ceramist is bringing the messy, yet soothing, hobby into the homes of the moneyed elite.
content: When Chelsea Hirschhorn organized a summer gathering in July at her house in Amagansett, N.Y., she made sure to include one party trick: pottery wheels. She hosted 15 adults for a ceramics class, where they sipped cocktails while spinning the wheels on her deck, shaping cups and bowls out of clay, followed by a paella feast and games of poker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Carol Rosenberg
title: Plea Deal May Be Near for One of the Bali Bombing Defendants
description: The case of a Guantánamo detainee charged by a military commission over terrorist attacks in Indonesia two decades ago is no longer joined to that of two other defendants.
content: A Guantánamo detainee accused of being an accessory to deadly terrorist attacks in Indonesia two decades ago has severed his military commission case from that of his two co-defendants, a move that suggested a plea deal could be in the works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Doja Cat Goes Horror Pop, and 12 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Peter Gabriel, Lauren Mayberry, Oneohtrix Point Never and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: In Monitoring Child Sex Abuse, Apple Is Caught Between Safety and Privacy
description: An advocacy group is starting a $2 million campaign calling for the company to better police materials on its products and services.
content: In 2021, Apple was embroiled in controversy over a plan to scan iPhones for child sexual abuse materials. Privacy experts warned that governments could abuse the system, and the backlash was so severe that Apple eventually abandoned the plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Pay Gains Are Slowing, Easing Worries on Inflation
description: The August increase was the smallest since early last year, a welcome sign for Federal Reserve policymakers.
content: American workers got smaller pay increases in August. That could be welcome news for policymakers at the Federal Reserve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Promise and Risk of Biden’s War on Drug Prices
description: Lowering the prices of vital drugs is worthwhile, but innovation could suffer if the government isn’t careful.
content: It’s pretty funny that the Biden administration persists in describing its program to lower what Medicare pays for 10 widely used prescription drugs as a “negotiation” with the manufacturers. If the companies refuse the government’s offer, they face excise taxes on the drugs’ prices that “range from 185.71 percent to 1,900 percent of the selected drug’s price depending on the duration of noncompliance,” according to the Congressional Research Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root
title: DocGo Used Unregistered Guards at Migrant Hotels, N.Y. Officials Charge
description: Security firms hired by DocGo, a medical services firm that was given a $432 million no-bid migrant services contract by New York City, used unauthorized guards.
content: More than 50 security guards hired to protect asylum seekers bused upstate from New York City by a troubled migrant contractor are working without proper authorization, a New York Department of State investigation found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I’m Dying of Cancer. Do I Have to Tell Anyone?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the information we owe our loved ones when terminally ill.
content: I am 76 and have lived a full and interesting life. My doctor recently gave me the news that the cancer I was treated for last year has returned and metastasized. I have started a course of immunotherapy treatments that, hopefully, should keep the cancer at bay for roughly the next two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The Forgotten Man
description: Walk-off wins used to be celebrated at home plate with the player who scored. At some point, without explanation, the emphasis flipped to the batter.
content: Ray Knight scored one of the most famous runs in baseball history, jumping onto home plate and into a sea of gleeful Mets teammates to end Game 6 of the 1986 World Series. It was a wild outpouring of joy from a team that played hard and celebrated harder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Officials Will Parse Jobs Numbers to Assess Economy’s Momentum
description: The employment report could be an important factor as central bankers contemplate the future of interest rate policy.
content: Federal Reserve officials are likely to closely watch employment numbers on Friday for further signs that the economy’s momentum is slowing, an important consideration for them in deciding whether to lift interest rates further.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Ban or Embrace? Colleges Wrestle With A.I.-Generated Admissions Essays.
description: A.I. chatbots could facilitate plagiarism on college applications or democratize student access to writing help. Or maybe both.
content: Rick Clark, the executive director of undergraduate admission at the Georgia Institute of Technology, and his staff spent weeks this summer pretending to be high school students using A.I. chatbots to fill out college applications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Conferences Are Changing. The Sport Is, Too.
description: This season is the last before new-look leagues and an expanded playoff will make the sport feel much different. More change came Friday with California, Stanford and Southern Methodist joining the Atlantic Coast Conference.
content: When the college football season kicks off in earnest this Labor Day weekend, it will be a test to keep an eye on the ball. The focus for a few days may be on blocking, tackling and quick-trigger assessments of who’s up and who’s down, but then what in a sport that is on the cusp of unprecedented upheaval?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Police Hunt for Convicted Murderer Who Escaped Pennsylvania Prison
description: Danelo Cavalcante, a Brazilian national, escaped from a prison near Philadelphia days after receiving a life sentence for homicide.
content: The police were searching early Friday for a Brazilian man they warned was “extremely dangerous” after he escaped from a prison near Philadelphia, days after he was sentenced to life in prison for the fatal stabbing of his former girlfriend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: To Track a Storm, Keep the People in Its Path Front of Mind
description: The Weather Data team introduced a project that will track storms like Hurricane Idalia, which hit Florida this week.
content: On Sunday, Aug. 27, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration detected a weather pattern that had increased enough in size to be labeled a tropical storm. It would become Idalia, the ninth named storm to form in the Atlantic this year. By Tuesday, Idalia had been upgraded to a hurricane. And on Wednesday, it made landfall as a Category 3 hurricane, hitting a sparsely populated area of Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: At the U.S. Open, It’s Not Only Tennis That’s Being Celebrated
description: Events at the tournament highlight Pride, H.B.C.U.s and equal pay for women in sports.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at celebrations at the U.S. Open for social and cultural movements like Pride and H.B.C.U. Live, a tribute to historically Black colleges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: New Chaperones for Labor Day Revelry: N.Y.P.D. Drones Flying Overhead
description: The Police Department will send them up in Brooklyn to keep an eye on everything from major parades to backyard barbecues.
content: The beating of drums. The bleating of horns. And now: the buzz of police drones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle
title: Paris Becomes the First European Capital to Ban Rented Electric Scooters
description: But the city is adding bike lanes, and scooter companies are shifting their focus to electric bikes. E-scooters were involved in accidents resulting in the deaths of three people in Paris last year.
content: As Paris’s experiment with e-scooters came to an end on Friday, Anne-Marie Moreno set out on her morning walk feeling just a little more peaceful. Ms. Moreno, a 78-year-old retiree who was knocked over by a man riding an electric scooter a few years back, was luxuriating in the calm of her neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Making It Official With a Song and a Scroll
description: Dr. Stephen Meeneghan, a naturopathic doctor, was hesitant when he received a message on a dating app from Ryan Cassata, a transgender advocate and musician. Yet they clicked right away.
content: Ryan Otto Cassata had no intention of falling in love when he met Dr. Stephen Vincent Lee Meeneghan on Aug. 10, 2021 on the gay dating app Scruff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Rau
title: Federal Officials Propose New Nursing Home Standards to Increase Staffing
description: Citing worker shortages, nursing home operators said the standard could not be met without additional funding for higher wages.
content: The nation’s most thinly staffed nursing homes would be required to hire more workers under new rules proposed on Friday by the Biden administration, the greatest change to federal nursing home regulations in three decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Readers Share What Has Brought Them Joy in 2023
description: You’ve danced in the rain, dived off a cliff, planted a native garden and savored other delightful moments.
content: It’s Friday. You shared what has brought you joy in 2023. Plus, ways to celebrate California’s extraordinary biodiversity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: West Coast Dockworkers Ratify Contract
description: The six-year agreement is expected to increase traffic at Pacific ports, which had sagged because of the prospect of a walkout.
content: Dockworkers at ports along the West Coast have ratified a new contract, securing a sweeping agreement set to last six years and expected to ease tensions after cargo shipments were diverted to other regions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Wolfram and Campbell Robertson
title: Escaped Convict Still at Large Outside Philadelphia
description: Hundreds of law officers were searching for a Brazilian national who escaped from prison two weeks after being convicted of first-degree murder.
content: Hundreds of law enforcement officers were scouring the railways, creeks and roads in a suburban county near Philadelphia on Friday, looking for a man who escaped from prison a little over two weeks after being convicted of first-degree murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Are We Finally Ready to Take Tammy Wynette Seriously?
description: The unsung godmother of so-called “sad girl” music — and one of pop’s most wrenching chroniclers of feminized pain — has long been misunderstood.
content: Earlier this month, at a concert in Arkansas, Lana Del Rey covered a song she’d never played live before: Tammy Wynette’s “Stand by Your Man.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Pope’s Remarks on ‘Reactionary’ U.S. Catholics Rankle, and Resonate
description: Where Francis sees rigid ideology replacing faith in the conservative American Catholic hierarchy, his critics see a struggle to preserve traditions and teachings they saw as settled.
content: When Pope Francis spoke of “a very strong, organized, reactionary attitude” that opposes him within the Roman Catholic Church in the United States and, in comments that became public this week, warned against letting “ideologies replace faith,” some American Catholics recognized their church immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Racehorse Deaths in Saratoga Renew Old Worries and Prompt Reforms
description: New York racing officials, addressing a deepening concern for the industry, say they will use diagnostic technology and synthetic tracks to keep horses safe.
content: It has become an all-too-common scenario: a thoroughbred suffers a ghastly injury before a packed grandstand and a national television audience and has to be euthanized by injection on the track. This past Saturday at Saratoga Race Course, an undefeated colt named New York Thunder was just strides from winning a $500,000 stakes race when he stumbled and unseated his rider.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Venice: Emma Stone Is a Bizarro Barbie in ‘Poor Things’
description: In the wild new comedy from Yorgos Lanthimos (“The Favourite”), Stone plays a sexually questing woman with the mind of an infant.
content: “What was I made for?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Sasha Waltz’s Dance Company: 30 Years of Giving Form to Feeling
description: As Waltz’s Berlin troupe commemorates its anniversary, its founder looks back on the lessons of those years, and forward to what comes next.
content: Thirty years ago, the young German choreographer Sasha Waltz founded a small contemporary dance company in Berlin. The newly reunified city wasn’t exactly a hub for modern dance, but when the wall came down on Nov. 9, 1989, Waltz, then living in Amsterdam, felt compelled to go there. “It wasn’t an artistic choice,” she said recently. “But it was such a unique moment. I knew I wanted to be part of this transformation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Ukraine Has Made ‘Notable Progress’ in the Last 72 Hours, the U.S. Said.
description: Also, new staffing rules for nursing homes. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: Ukrainian forces notched victories this week against two lines of Russian defense, according to a White House spokesman, who called the advances “notable progress” in Kyiv’s counteroffensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Norman Pfeiffer, Bicoastal Architect of Civic Spaces, Dies at 82
description: His global portfolio was dominated by projects that helped revitalize downtown Los Angeles and restore landmarks in New York.
content: Norman H. Pfeiffer, a bicoastal architect who for more than a half-century restored, reimagined and created civic spaces that enhanced New York landmarks and helped revitalize downtown Los Angeles, died on Aug. 23 at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: The Internet Takes Some Time Off
description: It’s the worst time of the year to be online.
content: Last week, I saw more posts than I could count citing a study that claims Aug. 24 is the day of the year when the most people call out of work sick (or “sick”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Fowler
title: In Georgia, One Republican Says, ‘We Will Do What Is Right’
description: There the focus is on Donald Trump, and the elected leaders owe a lot of their political strength to a segment of voters signaling a desire to enter a post-Trump era.
content: Georgia’s 16 electoral votes and a voting population that has supported both Democrats and Republicans at the top of the ticket in recent years keep the state one of few true battlegrounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Flynn Berry
title: In Stephen King’s Latest, Beware the Kindly Old Professors
description: His new novel, “Holly,” charges into thorny contemporary debates with a pair of unassuming fiends.
content: A friend of mine has become a scaredy-cat since having a baby. She has been forcing herself to watch horror movies through parted fingers, hoping they will steel her nerves for the frights of everyday life. I thought of my friend’s experiment while reading “Holly,” the new mystery from Stephen King: Here is a thriller scary enough to test its readers’ mettle — and toughen them up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Video Released of Officer Fatally Shooting Pregnant Black Woman
description: The family of Ta’Kiya Young said that her death outside a supermarket in Ohio was “not only avoidable, but also a gross misuse of power and authority.”
content: The police in a suburb of Columbus, Ohio, released body-camera footage on Friday of an officer fatally shooting a pregnant Black woman through the windshield of her car in the parking lot of a supermarket last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: No Charges Filed Over Death of Black Frenchman in Police Custody
description: Adama Traoré, 24, died in 2016 shortly after three officers pinned him to the ground during an arrest. His case became a symbol for activists protesting police violence in France.
content: A high-profile investigation into the death of Adama Traoré, a 24-year-old Black Frenchman who died in police custody in 2016, was officially closed on Friday without any charges against the three officers involved, according to lawyers for both parties.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: California Reconsiders Identity as Siren Song Fades
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 1, 2023.
content: “California is still the dream, but there’s not enough for everybody.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Promising unwavering support for Ukraine, the U.K. replaces its ex-soldier defense secretary with a savvy politician.
description: When Rishi Sunak replaced Liz Truss as British prime minister last fall, White House officials said they didn’t worry about his support for Ukraine because he left in place the respected soldier-turned-defense secretary Ben Wallace, who had orchestrated Britain’s unstinting military support of the Ukrainians.
content: When Rishi Sunak replaced Liz Truss as British prime minister last fall, White House officials said they didn’t worry about his support for Ukraine because he left in place the respected soldier-turned-defense secretary Ben Wallace, who had orchestrated Britain’s unstinting military support of the Ukrainians.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sparklehorse’s Long-Lost Album and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
description: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: A Scandal and Its Fallout Compound the British Museum’s Woes
description: After it fired a worker for theft and its director stepped down, the museum faces renewed calls to give back contested objects and an uphill battle to raise funds for refurbishment.
content: Visitors to the British Museum this week could be forgiven for thinking it was business as usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: How to Handle Conflict When You Hate Confrontation
description: There are healthy ways to have uncomfortable conversations, experts say.
content: I was in the middle seat on an airplane recently, during a flight to London, when a person behind me put her bare foot on my armrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Warming Could Push India Toward a Groundwater Crisis
description: Rising temperatures will increase irrigation needs, causing the country’s farmers to drain aquifers at triple the present rate, a new study estimated.
content: The warming climate could drive India to use up its groundwater much more rapidly in the coming decades, according to projections published Friday in the journal Science Advances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: John Isner Says Goodbye to Pro Tennis at the U.S. Open
description: A 6-foot-10 American, Isner had announced he would retire following the tournament. Losses in singles and doubles on Thursday ended a career known for powerful serves and a marathon match.
content: Josh Zipin of Manhattan rushed over from Arthur Ashe Stadium to the Grandstand court of the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center on Thursday hoping to catch the final set of John Isner’s singles match. Zipin, 34, said he had never seen Isner play live, and wanted to see what his “insane” serve looked like in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Theater to See Near N.Y.C. in September: ‘Ulysses,’ ‘The Pianist’ and More
description: Six shows and a fringe festival are among this month’s highlights in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and a bit beyond.
content: Headlines about the theater industry’s troubles have been easy to find lately: layoffs, closures, shrinking audiences and seasons. The good news? There’s still a lot of theater out there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: New Russian High School Textbooks Seek to Justify War in Ukraine
description: The textbooks, which cover Russian history from 1945 to present, also reimagine the brutality of Joseph Stalin’s policies.
content: As Russian high school students returned to classes after the summer break on Friday, they were expected to receive a heavily revised history textbook that claims that Ukraine is an “ultranationalist state” where “opposition is forbidden,” and that the United States is “the main beneficiary of the Ukrainian conflict.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Could Australia and New Zealand Become One Nation?
description: A New Zealand lawmaker talked about the idea last week, though a union is unlikely ever to take place.
content: Becoming a republic, legalizing same-sex marriage, changing the Constitution to establish an Aboriginal advisory body: To make these changes to Australian life requires — or has required — at least one nationwide vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Picking the Right Wall Color Isn’t Easy. Here’s How the Pros Do It.
description: We tagged along to see how Brigette Romanek, a celebrity designer in Los Angeles, chose a new color for her bedroom.
content: Everyone knows that paint is one of the easiest, cheapest ways to transform a room. What’s not so easy? Choosing the color.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 1, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 1, 2023.
content: An article on Sunday about attempts throughout history to find the Loch Ness Monster cited a British Library blog post and included a drawing about a purported 12th-century sighting of the Loch Ness Monster. The library has since confirmed that the post was an April Fools’ joke published in 2013 and has affixed a note that “the events it describes are, sadly, fictitious. We hope you had as much fun reading it as we did writing it.” (We might have enjoyed it too much.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cordell
title: Big Cats, Big Feelings
description: In four new picture books, lions, tigers and house cats stand in for young children as they rein in wild emotions or finally let out a roar.
content: When my daughter was 2, we were enjoying a nice afternoon at our local public library, but when it was time to go she wanted to stay. You can imagine the scene: A typically silent library suddenly erupts as a grimacing young father awkwardly carries his flailing, screaming, crying little one out the door. It was painful for everyone — for me, for the staff, for the patrons and, especially, for her. She was still learning how to communicate, how to respond appropriately to feelings like disappointment, anger and anxiety. When should we stay quiet and when should we roar? Four new books examine this question with the metaphorical help of large cats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Eileen Sullivan
title: Record Number of Families Cross Southern Border Illegally in August
description: The roughly 91,000 migrants who were arrested after crossing together as families exceeded a record set in May 2019, the height of the border crisis during the Trump administration.
content: Federal agents arrested a record number of migrant families who crossed the southern border illegally in August, two officials with preliminary data said, highlighting the Biden administration’s most prominent immigration challenge after rolling out new border policies this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Friday Briefing
description: The deaths of dozens of people in a fire in South Africa.
content: In one of the deadliest residential fires in South Africa’s history, at least 74 people, including at least a dozen children, were killed in Johannesburg after an early-morning blaze tore through a five-story building that city officials said had become a dilapidated settlement for squatters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Body Is Found in Search for Missing British Poet
description: The police said they had found a man’s body after a search for Gboyega Odubanjo, 27, who was last seen on Saturday at a music festival in England where he was set to perform.
content: The family of a British poet who disappeared last weekend from a music festival in England was in mourning after a body was found following a nearly weeklong search that drew national headlines and intense interest on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Parts of Las Vegas Strip Flood After Heavy Rain
description: At least one driver was rescued from a car, and others abandoned their vehicles, after flash flooding from fast-moving thunderstorms. More rain is expected through Saturday.
content: Fast-moving thunderstorms swept across the Las Vegas valley on Friday, causing flash flooding along parts of the Las Vegas Strip as the region braced for more rain into Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Adventures in the Serengeti
description: Robert Logan opens our solving weekend with an abundance of debut entries.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Texas Is the Latest State to Drop the ‘Tampon Tax’
description: So far, 24 states have eliminated sales taxes on period products that have been criticized as discriminatory.
content: On Friday, a bipartisan Texas bill that eliminates sales taxes on menstrual products went into effect, making it the 24th state in the country, as well as District of Columbia, to remove what is colloquially known as the “tampon tax.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: raucous
description: This word has appeared in 323 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word raucous has appeared in 323 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 11 in “Gotta Save the Castle? Start a Podcast” by Elizabeth Paton:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Iverson
title: Easy Mode: Clues for Sept. 1
description: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
content: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Thai King Commutes Former Prime Minister’s Sentence
description: Thaksin Shinawatra’s eight-year punishment was reduced to one year, days after his return from self-imposed exile. He remains one of the country’s most influential politicians.
content: Thailand’s king has granted a partial pardon to the ousted former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, commuting his eight-year prison sentence to a year, just days after the politician returned to the country from 15 years of exile, the nation’s official journal reported Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson, Keith Bradsher and Olivia Wang
title: U.S. Officials Are Streaming to China. Will Beijing Return the Favor?
description: Such visits could help convey Beijing’s interest in stabilizing ties with Washington. But China has been noncommittal.
content: When Gina Raimondo, the secretary of commerce, left China this week, it marked the end of a three-month diplomatic blitz by the Biden administration to try to stabilize ties with Beijing and arrest a free fall in the relationship that had raised concerns about the risk of conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: In the Wake of Wildfires, Maui Weddings Persevere
description: Some couples are continuing to plan nuptials on the island recently devastated by wildfires. “Moving forward and capturing positive emotions is to be of service,” one local photographer said.
content: Tara Lee Murphy photographed a late-morning wedding ceremony at Pacific’o on the Beach, a popular restaurant in downtown Lahaina, on Maui, on August 8. Ms. Murphy, who owns Tara Lee Photography, described the wedding day as the windiest she has ever seen. Ms. Murphy grew up in Maui, playing under Lahaina’s banyan tree as her mother worked at the Lahaina Arts Society nearby. It was so gusty on the beach, with winds reaching 70 miles per hour, that photographing the couple took extra care, like shooting in locations blocked by buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Mitch McConnell May Be Experiencing Small Seizures, Doctors Suggest
description: Two episodes, where the Republican senator froze and did not respond to some questions, may be symptoms of a serious illness, according to neurologists not involved in his medical care.
content: A four-line letter, signed by the attending physician of Congress and released by Senator Mitch McConnell on Thursday, suggested that his recent spells of speechlessness were linked to “occasional lightheadedness” perhaps brought on by his recovery from a concussion last winter or “dehydration.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: One Dead After Sports Riot. (It Was a Goat, and It Was Already Dead.)
description: In Kyrgyzstan, angry spectators stormed the field and threw stones after a kok-boru game.
content: Frequently, spectators are angry with the refereeing at a game. Once in a while, that anger spins out of control, and people are hurt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Pigs in a Blanket, the Undisputed Party Champions
description: Swiped through your favorite sauce, they’re equal parts retro, nostalgia and comfort.
content: In the waning days of summer, taking the Cooking newsletter out for a spin can feel a bit like speed dating. Who’s filling in for Sam and Melissa? Is it Julia? Priya? Mia? Today, at the start of a long weekend that brings an end to vacation season, I’ll be your date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: You’ve Heard of K-Beauty. Now Try K-Perfume
description: In opening a brick and mortar store, Elorea broadens the offerings of the perfumery.
content: Inside Elorea, a sleek new Korean perfumery in Manhattan’s NoLIta neighborhood, whose name is a portmanteau of “elements” and “Korea,” you will find paintings and pottery by Korean and Korean American artists, a cafe offering a chocolate and perfume pairing and shop attendants dressed entirely in black, eager to explain the brand’s gender-neutral fragrance collections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Tourists Were Told to Avoid Maui. Many Workers Want Them Back.
description: A plunge in tourism after a disastrous fire has already crippled the economy in Maui. Now, some locals who wanted visitors to stay away are urging them back.
content: In the first few days after an inferno leveled the Hawaiian town of Lahaina, the directive to tourists was emphatic: Stay away. And tourists, with a few exceptions, complied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
title: Filthy Toilets, No Showers and Criminal Landlords: Life in a South African Firetrap
description: After harrowing escapes from the apartment fire in Johannesburg that killed at least 74 people, residents described how they managed to build lives with no legal water or electricity, and very little privacy.
content: As Tom Mandala leaned out the fifth-floor window of his burning apartment building in Johannesburg early Thursday, it felt as if the only decision left to make was how to die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Impact of Hollywood Strikes on Jobs Goes Beyond the Strikers
description: Walkouts by screenwriters and actors have meant less work in fields that cater to the TV and film industry.
content: One reason the August employment report wasn’t stronger: Television and movie production has largely halted since a deadlock in contract negotiations between major studios and unions that represent screenwriters and actors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: U.S. Knew About Migrant Killings by Saudi Forces Earlier Than Previously Disclosed
description: The State Department says diplomats in Riyadh learned of the atrocities from research groups last summer, contradicting an earlier statement that the United States was not aware until December.
content: The State Department said U.S. diplomats in Saudi Arabia had first heard reports of a dramatic increase in lethal violence against migrants and asylum seekers by that nation’s border forces in the summer of last year and had immediately asked officials at “high levels” of the Saudi government to investigate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Joel Fagliano delivers a puzzle filled with visual tricks and tests.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Joel Fagliano has a daily presence in The Times’s Games lineup, both as a puzzles editor and the regular constructor of the mini crossword. He also makes a lot of diverse puzzles, including Puns and Anagrams. I was surprised to see that it’s been five years since his last one. Too long! I imagine that the mini has become an outlet for some of the whimsical clues that comprise a PandA, as these inventive grids are called.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: An $80 Million Duplex Is the Priciest Closing (So Far) This Year
description: The apartment sold at 220 Central Park South, a.k.a. the city’s most expensive building. The Woolworth Building also sold a penthouse, for $30 million, well below the asking price.
content: The year’s most expensive sale in New York City took place in August at 220 Central Park South in Midtown, where an expansive duplex in the villa portion of the park-facing condo complex closed at $80 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 7, Episode 4 Recap: Flight Risk
description: Mike gets involved unwittingly in a fugitive’s flight from justice. Chuck wouldn’t know anything about that, would he?
content: A house divided against itself cannot stand. At least, that’s the hope of Wendy and Wags. Tied for second place as the people most responsible for the multi-billion-dollar success of Axe Cap — behind only Axe himself — they have been accepted into the brain trust of Axe’s usurper, Mike Prince. He relies on their very particular sets of skills, skills acquired over very long careers. What he doesn’t know is that they’re attempting to use those same skills to take him down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexa Weibel
title: An Easy, Summery Tomato Pasta That’s Ready for Fall
description: Caramelized tomatoes are paired with white beans in this season-bridging weeknight dinner.
content: If the allure of summertime cooking is its lack of effort, and winter’s is its opportunity to linger (and labor) in the warmth of the kitchen, this busy back-to-school period requires something in between. This roasted white bean and tomato pasta reflects the season: You might still be hoarding cherry tomatoes at the farmers’ market, but the cooling weather may just have you contemplating turning on the oven again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: ‘It’s Different When It’s Your Little Girl’
description: Alex Smith returned to play pro football after a horrific leg injury nearly killed him. Nothing about his recovery prepared him for the helplessness of watching his daughter battle a brain tumor.
content: This was the Alex Smith comeback years in the making.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Hard Right Injects Immigration Into Spending Fight, Raising Shutdown Fears
description: The House Freedom Caucus has said it will not support any spending measure — even a stopgap bill to keep the government open while lawmakers negotiate — without a sweeping border crackdown.
content: Hard-right House Republicans are threatening to block a stopgap bill to keep the government funded unless it includes a security crackdown along the U.S.-Mexico border, escalating fears of a shutdown within weeks and injecting the supercharged politics of immigration into an already fraught stalemate over federal spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: Ed Ruscha’s ‘Chocolate Room’ Still Tantalizes
description: “I was a little bit tired of making conventional pictures”: The artist on recreating his bittersweet installation, first seen in 1970, for the Museum of Modern Art.
content: A rich perfume wafts through the sixth floor of the Museum of Modern Art, where the installation of Ed Ruscha’s full-dress survey “Now Then” is underway. You sense it before you see it: a room where the white walls are turning velvety brown. A chocolate room.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Michael Oher and ‘White Savior Syndrome’
description: Adoptive parents discuss interracial adoptions. Also: McConnell’s health; U.S. Education Department; fighting climate change; coed bathrooms.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
title: Two Proud Boys Sentenced in Jan. 6 Sedition Case
description: Ethan Nordean, a ground commander of the far-right group, got 18 years, matching the longest Jan. 6 sentence so far. Dominic Pezzola, among the first rioters to enter the Capitol, received 10 years.
content: Two more members of the Proud Boys were sentenced to prison on Friday for their roles in the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with a ground commander in the far-right group, Ethan Nordean, given 18 years, and Dominic Pezzola, the man who set off the initial breach of the building by smashing a window with a riot shield, getting 10 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Bill Pinkney, Globe-Circling Sailor Who Set a Racial Mark, Dies at 87
description: He was the first Black person to sail alone by way of the arduous southern route, rounding the perilous Cape Horn and withstanding storms and loneliness.
content: Bill Pinkney, the first Black sailor to circumnavigate the globe alone by the arduous southern route — rounding the five great capes of the earth’s southernmost points of land, most notably the fearsome Cape Horn — died on Thursday in Atlanta. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: Embracing Her Inner Drag King
description: “I pictured myself as my lover, a cisgender man, talking to a woman dressed to receive him as I always have.”
content: “Slow-moving, slow-talking, with a melancholy sense of humor, my lover was in many ways my ideal of a man,” writes Maxine Swann in this week’s Modern Love essay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
title: The Secretive Billionaires Building a Tech Utopia + Casey’s External Brain + HatGPT
description: From building productivity apps to building new cities — tech tries to reinvent the world, again.
content: A group of tech titans is gobbling up land north of San Francisco with aspirations to alleviate the Bay Area’s housing crisis, promote innovation, and experiment with new forms of governance. It’s not the first time ultra-wealthy people have tried to build the place of their dreams. Will this time be any different?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarang Shidore
title: American Power Just Took a Big Hit
description: For the United States, the expansion of BRICS is a challenge but also an opportunity.
content: For more than a decade, the United States mostly ignored BRICS. The grouping, formed by Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa, rarely registered on Washington’s radar. When it did, the impulse — as shown by Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, recently stressing that the coalition is not “some kind of geopolitical rival” — was to downplay the group’s significance. Western commentators, for their part, largely painted BRICS as either a sign of Chinese attempts to dominate the global south or little more than a talking shop. Some even called for its dissolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: In Visit to Tiny Flock in Mongolia, Pope Has an Eye on Russia and China
description: The pontiff arrived Friday on a trip that the Vatican said was meant to encourage the fewer than 1,500 Catholics there. But it also brings him close to two great powers that have vexed him.
content: Pope Francis has long expressed a desire to visit Russia and China in hopes of healing the church’s historical rifts and ensuring the faith’s future in the populous East. On Friday, he came very close, landing in Mongolia, a country sandwiched between the two geopolitical giants, with a minuscule Catholic population that no pope has visited before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patti Davis
title: Behind Dianne Feinstein’s Headlines Lies Another, Untold Story
description: The caregiving journey always feels like a pilgrim’s path, lonely and strange.
content: Dianne Feinstein makes news these days for the health challenges that seem to keep mounting, but behind her story is another, which few pay attention to. It’s the story of the family and friends who are now caregivers, who juggle the unpredictability of the day-to-day with the inevitability of the long term. No matter how many people have traveled ahead of us on the caregiving journey and have shared their experiences, it always feels like a pilgrim’s path, lonely and strange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova and Gaya Gupta
title: Nobel Foundation Invites Russia, Belarus and Iran to 2023 Prize Ceremony
description: The executive director of the Nobel Foundation said it was reversing course from a year ago in an effort lower tensions at a time of growing geopolitical divisions.
content: Reversing course from last year, the Nobel Foundation has extended an invitation to the Nobel Prize ceremonies in December to representatives from Russia and Belarus, who were not invited in 2022 because of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Leaked Recording of U.A.E. Officials Reveals the Nation’s Concern Over Its Public Image
description: As it prepares to host a global climate summit, officials discussed ways to counter criticism of the Gulf state’s human rights policies.
content: When the United Arab Emirates hosts this year’s United Nations climate summit, it will elevate the Gulf nation’s global profile. But the conference is also inviting scrutiny of the Emirates’ record on human rights as well as its position as a leading oil producer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Conor Dougherty
title: How the Dream of Building a California City From Scratch Got Started
description: A former Goldman Sachs trader moved to the Bay Area to make it in tech. He ended up buying rural land with money from some of Silicon Valley’s wealthiest people.
content: What if you built a new city from the ground up? The idea has tantalized urban planners and utopian dreamers for centuries. In 2017, Jan Sramek joined their crusade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scoop Jackson
title: A Splashy History of N.B.A. Fashion, On and Off the Court
description: From Michael Jordan to Russell Westbrook, Dennis Rodman to LeBron James, “Fly” traces the looks that have defined basketball style from the beginning.
content: When I was growing up, there was a thing called “the ballplayer look.” It served two essential purposes: to show the world you were a hooper, and also that you were fly. It could be the way you rocked your socks and shorts, the sneaks you chose on the court, your haircut, the type of earring you wore. It all came down to a style that signaled basketball was your calling card.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin and Graham Bowley
title: Hezbollah Sanctions Case Highlights Frailties in the Art Market
description: In its indictment of a collector accused of helping the militant group, U.S. prosecutors presented evidence of how easily art sales can be used to evade sanctions and launder money.
content: Earlier this year, a Lebanese art collector was accused of money laundering and violating terrorism-related sanctions in a federal indictment that focused attention on the reported beneficiary of some of his activities: the militant group Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Where Should Agnostics Go on Sundays?
description: In search of the ‘church for the nones.’
content: Perry Bacon, a columnist for The Washington Post, has an essay about his experience with Christianity entitled “I left the church — and now long for a ‘church for the nones.’” The “nones,” as this newsletter’s readers probably know, are the growing share of Americans who don’t identify with any religious tradition, and the sense that we’re losing something when churchgoing lapses has shown up in recent essays by my colleagues Jessica Grose and Nick Kristof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jackie Frere
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: A New Hulu Series Celebrates the Many Faces of Black Success
description: A hybrid of talk show and dinner party, “The Conversations Project” pairs gourmet meals with provocative questions about being Black in America.
content: Seat eight highly successful Black people around a dinner table and prompt them to discuss reparations and hairstyles and Kanye West over crayfish bisque and roast duck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg and Haruka Sakaguchi
title: All That Empty Office Space Belongs to Someone
description: What happens if the nearly 100 million square feet of workplace real estate stays empty?
content: At an office in SoHo, rows of desks sit empty, while a shaggy dog — shadowing an owner nostalgic for work-from-home comforts — wanders the conference rooms. At a tech workplace downtown, a gaggle of 20-somethings divide into teams, calling out “Who’s on the Orange team?” and “We’re going to kill it!” as part of a game night enticing them back to in-person work. On the subway, commuters delight in a once-unimaginable indulgence: bag-spreading across two seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: How They Got ‘Beaten to Death’ Onscreen
description: The director Sam Curtain and the actor Thomas Roach discuss making a new ultraviolent horror movie so grueling that it left its lead hospitalized at the end of the shoot.
content: From “Slumber Party Massacre” to “It Follows,” some of the most memorable horror movie titles double as pint-size plot summaries. That’s the case for Sam Curtain’s “Beaten to Death,” a mercilessly violent new movie that has critics dog-earing their thesauruses for superlatives to describe its savagery. So far, there’s “gauntlet of extreme horror” and “non-stop nightmare.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Time to Expose the Liar at Work?
description: When you discover a co-worker is fabricating her own performance numbers, think carefully before confronting her.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Kia and Hyundai Helped Enable a Crime Wave. They Should Pay for It.
description: The carmakers are being sued for failing to install a basic anti-theft device in millions of cars.
content: In a recent analysis of data from 37 American cities, the Council on Criminal Justice, a nonpartisan think tank, suggested a hopeful trend — the pandemic-era spike in crime may have peaked. The homicide rate has dropped significantly over the last year, based on data from 30 American cities. In many places, just about all types of violent crimes are down, in some areas substantially — in Atlanta, for instance, there have been 21 percent fewer aggravated assaults, 28 percent fewer homicides and 56 percent fewer rapes than at this point in 2022, according to police department data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: U.S. Hiring Settles Into a Lower Gear
description: Employers added 187,000 jobs in August and unemployment rose to 3.8 percent as the economy continued to lose momentum built up after pandemic lockdowns.
content: The United States labor market is starting to look a lot like its old self — the one that existed before the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: As Ukraine’s Fight Grinds On, Talk of Negotiations Becomes Nearly Taboo
description: Discussion of a Plan B, should Ukraine fail to win a total victory, has become more fraught than ever, say those who have tried.
content: Stian Jenssen, the chief of staff to the secretary general of NATO, recently had his knuckles rapped when he commented on possible options for an end to the war in Ukraine that did not envision a complete Russian defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Airline Sold Tickets for Already Canceled Flights, Watchdog Group Says
description: Australia’s consumer commission said in legal proceedings that Qantas, the country’s national carrier, had sold tickets for routes it never intended to fly.
content: Qantas Airways, Australia’s national airline, sold thousands of tickets for flights that it had already canceled, the country’s consumer watchdog said in a lawsuit against the carrier, and left travelers scrambling to make alternative arrangements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maxine Swann
title: Why I Dress (and Act) Like a Man
description: Tired of being deferential to men in my relationships, I decided to create my own drag king persona.
content: Slow moving, slow talking, with a melancholy sense of humor, my lover was in many ways my ideal of a man. So when we were told to imitate a man in my drag king workshop, he was the person who came to mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: DeSantis Super PAC’s Urgent Plea to Donors: ‘We Need 50 Million Bucks’
description: In an audio recording made just before the first G.O.P. debate, the super PAC’s chief strategist disparaged rivals and described an expensive attempt to thwart Donald Trump in Iowa.
content: Hours before the Republican Party’s first presidential debate, the chief strategist for the super PAC that has effectively taken over Ron DeSantis’s presidential campaign met with donors in Milwaukee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: What to Know About the Fire That Killed at Least 74 in Johannesburg
description: The blaze, one of the worst residential ones in South Africa’s history, occurred in a building that officials and locals say had become an overcrowded death trap for the hundreds who lived there.
content: A fire that killed at least 74 people in a five-story building in downtown Johannesburg on Thursday has prompted calls for the authorities to do more to address an acute housing crisis and crack down on the city’s hundreds of such derelict, overcrowded buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Applying to College? Here’s How A.I. Tools Might Hurt, or Help.
description: ChatGPT might change the application essay forever.
content: I spent the last week talking with university officials, teachers and high school seniors about the dreaded college admissions essay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The One-Handed Backhand Is on the Way to Extinction
description: How can something so beautiful to watch, a stroke so etched into tennis history, be so exploitable — and why have a dwindling handful of players remained loyal to it?
content: Behold the beautiful and beloved one-handed backhand, but do it quickly, because time is running short for tennis’s lustiest shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: Finding a Lifetime Karaoke Partner Miles From Home
description: Vipin Chamakkala and Amanda Robson, who both work in venture capital, met two years ago while working temporarily in New York.
content: When Vipin Mathew Chamakkala first spotted Amanda Elizabeth Robson at his previous company’s karaoke outing in Manhattan’s Koreatown in May 2021, he wondered what an interloper was doing there.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Ultimate Tammy Wynette Primer
description: Hear her biggest hits, deeper cuts and tributes from disciples.
content: For years, I’ve been waiting for the right moment to write about one of my favorite country singers, the great, oft-misunderstood Tammy Wynette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Hu
title: Audiobook of the Week: Meryl Streep Would Like to Tell You a Story
description: The actor narrates Ann Patchett’s sentimental new novel, “Tom Lake,” about a Midwestern family.
content: Deciding what audiobook to listen to requires its own special calculus, related to but distinct from the factors we consider when picking a book off a shelf. From the Book Review’s own endless listening, we will select and review a different title each week, from a range of genres, to help you decide. See you next Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Nancy Buirski, Award-Winning Documentary Filmmaker, Dies at 78
description: She won Emmy and Peabody Awards for “The Loving Story,” about a Virginia couple’s successful challenge to a ban on interracial marriage.
content: Nancy Buirski, an Emmy and Peabody Award-winning documentary filmmaker whose eye was honed as a still photographer and picture editor, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: One of the Biggest Cable Companies Says Cable TV Isn’t Working
description: Charter Communications told investors Friday that its fraught negotiation with Disney was a sign of a larger problem with the traditional cable-TV business model.
content: One of the biggest cable companies in the United States has a message for media companies, its major partners in a decades-old business: The traditional cable-TV model is broken, and it needs to be fixed or abandoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Why Are So Many Players Getting Sick at the U.S. Open?
description: Ons Jabeur has won two rounds despite having flu symptoms, but Dominic Thiem was forced to retire from his second-round match with an illness.
content: Early in the second set of her second-round match on Thursday night, a ball bounced just past Ons Jabeur’s reach, and she lost the point, throwing her arms up in exasperation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Michael Simon Johnson, Will Reid, Alex Stern, Rikki Novetsky, Carlos Prieto, Paige Cowett, Devon Taylor, Chelsea Daniel, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: Arizona’s Pipe Dream
description: Water levels in aquifers are falling nationwide. Could taking salt out of ocean water be the answer?
content: A Times investigation revealed that in much of the United States, communities and farms are pumping out groundwater at alarming rates. Aquifers are shrinking nationwide, threatening supplies of drinking water and the country’s status as a food superpower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: What I’m Reading: Buried Secrets
description: In countries that have emerged from brutal 20th-century dictatorships, the past isn’t staying in the past.
content: Even the best-laid plans, in my experience, often don’t survive contact with vacations. Unlike some past trips that shall remain nameless but know what they did, thankfully this time around there were no hurricanes, passport thefts, norovirus outbreaks or other crises. But it turned out my reading list was way off base: the last thing I wanted, while baking in beach-town heat, was to read novels about others doing the same. So “The Guest” remains firmly in my to-read pile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Gil Brandt, 91, Dies; Helped Make the Cowboys ‘America’s Team’
description: As talent evaluator for nearly 30 years, he built Dallas into an N.F.L. powerhouse through the use of computer technology and other innovations.
content: Gil Brandt, who in nearly 30 years as a scout and talent evaluator helped build the Dallas Cowboys into a National Football League powerhouse, died on Thursday in Dallas. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Shain
title: Can Plastic Recycling Ever Really Work?
description: Many plastics that carry the “chasing arrows” symbol, like soda cups and yogurt tubs, are rarely recycled. A new California law is raising the bar.
content: Jan Dell is a collector. But instead of art or action figures, she collects what she calls “bad plastic containers.” She is a connoisseur and a completist: Her specimens include lids from oatmeal canisters, cups from fast-food joints, cleaners wrapped in shrink sleeves, and many, many Amazon mailers. Each carries the familiar “chasing arrows” recycling symbol; none, she believes, will ever be recycled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Aida Alami
title: French Citizen Killed After Straying Into Algerian Waters
description: The man was one of several French-Moroccan dual citizens vacationing in northern Morocco when their water scooters, low on fuel, drifted across the maritime border and the coast guard opened fire.
content: Algerian coast guard forces shot and killed a French citizen and detained another after they strayed on water scooters into Algerian waters from Morocco, where they were vacationing, the French authorities said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Mohamed al-Fayed, Tycoon Whose Son Died With Diana, Is Dead at 94
description: An Egyptian businessman, he built an empire of trophy properties in London, Paris and elsewhere, but it was all overshadowed by a fatal car crash that stunned the world.
content: Mohamed al-Fayed, the Egyptian business tycoon whose empire of trophy properties and influence in Europe and the Middle East was overshadowed by the 1997 Paris car crash that killed his eldest son, Dodi, and Diana, the Princess of Wales, died on Wednesday. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Rosalind Brewer Steps Down as Walgreens Chief After a Short Tenure
description: She was one of the few women to run a Fortune 500 company, and when she was appointed she was the only Black woman to hold that position.
content: Rosalind Brewer, the chief executive of Walgreens Boots Alliance, is stepping down from the position she has occupied since March 2021, the retail and pharmacy chain announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Hartman and Todd Heisler
title: Staking the Future on a Stretch of Sidewalk in Brooklyn
description: Immigrant street vendors have been setting up shop on Fifth Avenue in Sunset Park for decades. A pecking order loosely allocates the spaces, but the setup is not worry free.
content: On a recent Sunday, Oliver Hernandez jumped out of the van driven by his partner. It was 6 a.m. The mom-and-pop shops along Fifth Avenue in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, were shuttered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Borges
title: 7 Books for Better Sleep
description: We asked clinicians and researchers to share their favorite recommendations.
content: A good night’s sleep has become increasingly elusive for many of us — as we stay up for work, play or existential dread — and this is to our detriment. Not only do we feel the effects of poor sleep throughout the day, but research shows that chronic sleep loss has negative long-term effects on our heart health, brain function and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Grim Struggle Begins to Identify Victims in South African Fire
description: Families on Friday were trying to identify relatives caught in one of the deadliest residential fires in South African history, which health officials said would require DNA testing.
content: Some people gathered outside a mortuary in Johannesburg on Friday, fearing the worst for missing family members. Others went to hospital after hospital, desperately searching for friends and relatives, hoping against all odds that they were safe somewhere else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas Supreme Court Allows Transgender Medical Ban to Begin
description: The state’s highest court declined to stop a new law banning transition care for transgender minors from taking effect as legal challenges proceed.
content: The Texas Supreme Court allowed a new law banning transition care for transgender minors to go into effect on Friday, halting a range of medically-accepted treatments, including hormones and puberty blockers, in the nation’s most populous Republican-led state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: A Deadly Fire in Johannesburg, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: As Anniversary of Women’s Uprising Nears, Iran Cracks Down
description: Sept. 16 marks one year since Mahsa Amini died in the custody of the morality police, setting off months of protests. Authorities are trying to quell any new unrest.
content: The professor of artificial intelligence was a rising star at Iran’s elite Sharif University of Technology. He gained wider fame for his vocal support of the women-led uprising that rocked Iran last year. At one point, he refused to teach until Sharif students arrested in the government’s crackdown against protesters were released.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: The Forgotten Teenage Trailblazer of Women’s Tennis
description: Before Billie Jean King beat Bobby Riggs in the “Battle of the Sexes,” Phyllis Graber wanted to play tennis on a boys’ team. The rules said she couldn’t.
content: Growing up in Kew Gardens, Queens, in the 1960s, Phyllis Graber played stickball, handball and baseball, eventually falling for tackle football, which she played in Forest Park, the only girl who was interested. Concerned that she was “developing,” her parents encouraged her to shift her focus to something demanding less savagery. She found this vaguely ridiculous but chose tennis, a sport in which she excelled. While she would have been invaluable on any girls’ tennis team, Jamaica High School in 1970 did not have one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: We Used A.I. to Write Essays for Harvard, Yale and Princeton. Here’s How It Went.
description: A.I. chatbots can do a passable job of generating short essays. Whether their use on college applications is ethical is the subject of fierce debate.
content: As high school seniors begin working on their college applications, many are turning to A.I. chatbots like ChatGPT and Bard for assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: In a Crisis (or Two), They Both Knew Where to Turn for Help
description: Jennifer Lee and Dr. Sachin Jain bonded over commonalities in their upbringings. They also discovered, after separate car accidents, that they could count on each other.
content: While driving home from a work dinner in downtown Los Angeles in August 2021, Jennifer Lee’s Toyota Prius was suddenly struck in the side by another car that had run a red light. Ms. Lee had suffered whiplash, her car was badly damaged and she was in a state of shock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Reeling From Heartbreak, and Then ‘Penelope’ Showed Up
description: Alex Bechtel’s new musical, sort of “a pandemic parable,” gives voice to a mythical character in “The Odyssey.”
content: The composer and lyricist Alex Bechtel didn’t go looking for Penelope, the mythical character in “The Odyssey” famed for her clever weaving and steadfast endurance of long abandonment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin P. Russell
title: A Nicaraguan Novelist Betrayed by the Revolution He Helped Build
description: “I’m no longer a leader in the fight,” says Sergio Ramírez. “Now I’m just an author being punished for the words he writes.” His latest crime tale is out in English.
content: Sergio Ramírez has been forced into exile twice; once for his role in a revolution and once after writing, in a work of fiction, about what that revolution became. One thing he’s learned in the interim: Dictators lack imagination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof and Jillian Weinberger
title: America Has a Reading Problem. Mississippi Has a Solution.
description: As kids head back to school, Nicholas Kristof wants America to learn from the Magnolia State.
content: For decades, Mississippi had some of the worst reading and math scores in the country. That’s no longer true. Recently, the state’s third and fourth graders have improved significantly, and they’re now on par with the rest of the country. As kids head back to school, the New York Times Opinion columnist Nicholas Kristof explains what’s been called the Mississippi miracle and what other states can learn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Host of YouTube Parenting Channel Is Charged With Child Abuse
description: Ruby Franke, a Utah mother known for chronicling her strict parenting style, was arrested after one of her children ran to a neighbor’s house seeking help.
content: A Utah mother who chronicled her strict parenting style on YouTube and other social media channels was arrested and charged with aggravated child abuse this week after one of her children climbed out a window and ran to a nearby house seeking help, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Adam Satariano
title: Meta May Allow Instagram and Facebook Users in Europe to Pay to Avoid Ads
description: The subscription plan is a response to European Union policies and court rulings to restrict Meta’s data-collection practices.
content: Meta is considering paid versions of Facebook and Instagram that would have no advertising for users in the European Union, three people with knowledge of the company’s plans said, a response to regulatory scrutiny and a sign that how people experience technology in the United States and Europe may diverge because of government policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney Changes Gears in Suits Against DeSantis and Allies
description: Disney and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, who is running for president, have been sparring for more than a year over a special tax district that encompasses Disney World.
content: After a setback, Disney has changed its legal strategy in Florida, where the company is battling Gov. Ron DeSantis and his allies in court for control over Disney World’s growth plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bridgette Exman
title: This Summer, I Became the Book-Banning Monster of Iowa
description: There are no winners in the game of censorship.
content: A couple of weeks ago, before the start of another school year, I found myself standing in the middle of the stacks in our high school library, my heart sinking. I had come in search of five books that I needed to read to make the final determination about whether they would remain on the shelves for our students or be boxed up and stored in my office, not to be seen by the students under penalty of law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Stanford
title: After Hitting the Southeast, Idalia to Strengthen and Approach Bermuda
description: The remnants of the former hurricane, now a post-tropical cyclone, were forecast to strengthen into a tropical storm again over the weekend.
content: The remnants of Hurricane Idalia were forecast to regain strength and become a tropical storm again over the weekend as it approached Bermuda, days after the storm made landfall along Florida’s Gulf Coast and swept across the Southeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Europe’s ‘Tormented History’ Drives an Ambitious Macron Protégé
description: Clément Beaune, who had a double coming out as a gay man with Jewish roots, wants to be mayor of Paris, revive the center-left and build the united Europe he cherishes.
content: On a recent visit to Kyiv, Clément Beaune, the French transportation minister, stopped off in the Ukrainian port city of Odesa to pay homage to his Jewish forebears who fled pogroms for France around 1910, only to be deported by French authorities to Auschwitz in 1944 and murdered there by the Nazis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: A Dinner Party Menu That Finds Inspiration in Italy
description: Transport yourself to the Mediterranean with a roasted pepper antipasto, a succulent fish in tomato broth and an easy, showstopping plum tart from David Tanis.
content: I love this time of year, when summer produce is at its glorious best, even though I know it won’t last much longer. Its end brings ripe peppers of all sorts, in various shades of orange and scarlet, sweet from a season in the sun and far more delicious than the hothouse types could ever hope to be. Likewise, the deeply flavorful tomatoes we wait for all year are now ready to enjoy. Stone fruit is still going strong, with juicy peaches on display at every market stall. But it’s the late-season plums I’m most excited about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Vaccines for Fall
description: We offer a guide to fall vaccine shots.
content: Covid cases have risen. Flu season is approaching. And new vaccines for the virus known as R.S.V. recently became available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shreya Chattopadhyay
title: 6 New Paperback to Read This Week
description: This week's selection includes titles by Celeste Ng, Kendra Allen, Gary Gerstle and more.
content: This week's selection includes titles by Celeste Ng, Kendra Allen, Gary Gerstle and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz and Kevin Quealy
title: Visualizing the Latest Wave of N.C.A.A. Conference Realignment
description: In a chase for TV revenue, colleges have undertaken another wave of conference realignment, effectively ending the Pac-12.
content: In a chase for TV revenue, colleges have undertaken another wave of conference realignment, effectively ending the Pac-12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: How to Choose Paint Colors
description: How Brigette Romanek, a celebrity designer in Los Angeles, chose a new wall color for her bedroom.
content: How Brigette Romanek, a celebrity designer in Los Angeles, chose a new wall color for her bedroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Dowling
title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the video game Starfield, which is offering early access to those who buy the premium edition.
content: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the video game Starfield, which is offering early access to those who buy the premium edition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Sullivan
title: How to Read Olive Oil Labels
description: There's more to it than "extra virgin."
content: There's more to it than "extra virgin."
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Kornelis
title: Paranormal Festivity: A Small Town Celebrates U.F.O. Lore
description: Local legend has it that Elmwood, Wis., is a favorite visiting place for extraterrestrials.
content: Local legend has it that Elmwood, Wis., is a favorite visiting place for extraterrestrials.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The New York Times News Quiz, Sept. 1, 2023
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
content: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Big Number: $55,000
description: A new proposal from the Labor Department seeks to increase the salary threshold for overtime pay eligibility.
content: A new proposal from the Labor Department seeks to increase the salary threshold for overtime pay eligibility.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Labor Day Mattress, Bedding, and Pillow Deals 2023
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Power of Adult Immunization 2
description: For adults over 60, disease prevention is far more beneficial than treatment.
content: For adults over 60, disease prevention is far more beneficial than treatment.
source.name: The New York Times
